items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of overnight heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tomorrow morning, 05/10/2021.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Cotes, Loughborough, Zouch, Kegworth, Ratcliffe on Soar, Meadow Lane at Loughborough and the access road from Ratcliffe on Soar to Redhill Marina, and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.   We expect river levels to remain high until at least the 06/10/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are expected to rise on the River Cole and Dorcan Brook in response to heavy rainfall forecast overnight tonight, 4 October 2021. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected overnight tonight between 10pm and 7am, especially in the areas closest to the watercourses in Lower Stratton, Dorcan and east of Swindon. Heavy rainfall is forecast overnight between 9pm and 3am. We expect river levels to rise in response to this rainfall before starting to drop in the early hours of the morning.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing weed and trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 5 October 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight from Monday into Tuesday.
Heavy rainfall is forecast across East Devon and is forecast to cause river levels to rise.
Flooding is expected between 1am and 8am on Tuesday. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land in the floodplain and roads close to the river in the following areas. Cullompton, Willand, Culmstock, Hemyock, Bradninch, Broadclyst and Clyst St Mary.
Further scattered showers are forecast throughout Tuesday. 
River levels are expected to remain higher than normal throughout this period. Please take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
Our incident response staff are monitoring river levels. We will update this message on Tuesday morning or when the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall tonight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin from 01:00 tomorrow, 05/10/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peak:- Llanymynech 3.2m to 3.7m 05/10/21 at 11:00.   
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, which may cause river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 05/10/21 by 09:00, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses. Flooding is likely to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. This Flood Alert is likely to remain in place for several days, with further heavy rain forecast for Tuesday (05/10/2021). A Flood Warning is also in place for Keswick Campsite. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 05/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

The level of Derwentwater remains high following several days of rain.  Further heavy rain is forecast on Tuesday 05/10/2021 which will cause the water level to rise again. Areas most at risk of flooding include low lying land bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This Flood Warning is expected to remain in place for several days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this warning if necessary. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 05/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. 
We will continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. Scattered showers are forecast for today. Further potentially heavy showers are forecast overnight Monday into Tuesday, which may cause surface water issues and/or cause river levels to rise again. 

We will continue to monitor the situation closely. The weather remains unsettled for the rest of the week and heavy rainfall is possible, and we will reissue this flood alert if required.

The River Adur is already higher than normal, following showers Monday morning. Heavy rain is forecast between 01:00 and 06:00 Tuesday morning, which will cause river levels to rise again. From 05:00 Tuesday 05/10/2021, flooding could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge and may begin to approach buildings too. Scattered showers are possible during Tuesday, but the rest of the week is forecast to stay largely dry. The river should begin to fall by 22:00 Tuesday 05/10/2021, returning to near normal Wednesday afternoon. Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. Some roads, including those mentioned in this message, may be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast, and will issue a flood warning if confidence in property flooding increases. We will update this message by 11:00 Tuesday 05/10/2021.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: Water levels are high on Windermere, Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel due to the heavy rainfall over the weekend. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 05/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Over the weekend we have seen widespread heavy rainfall. This has meant that the River Roding has been rising. 
The main areas of concern are Abridge and Loughton.  Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river today on Monday 4th October. Flooding from surface water could also occur. 
We expect the river to remain high throughout Monday. Further heavy rainfall is forecast from Monday night into Tuesday and river levels may rise in response to this. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages..
This message will be updated by 8pm today or earlier if the situation changes

River levels are forecast to rise on the River Wey, Preston Brook, River Jordan due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Wey, Preston Brook, River Jordan.

Heavy rain overnight is expected to cause the river level to rise peaking at 01:00 AM on 05/10/2021.

Flooding is possible at the River Wey to Radipole Lake, Preston Brook and River Jordan from 09:30 PM on 04/10/2021.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast into tomorrow morning.

River levels will rise rapidly at the Broadwey, Upwey gauge.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this alert if necessary.
Consider activating any property flood protection products if available.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 PM on 04/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Lim, River Char, River Winniford, Simene River, River Brit, River Asker, River Mangerton, River Bride due to heavy rainfall .
River levels will be at their highest between 01:00 AM and 02:00 AM on 05/10/2021.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Lim, River Char, River Winniford, Simene River, River Brit, River Asker, River Mangerton, River Bride from 11:00 PM on 04/10/2021.

Heavy rainfall is forecast overnight which will cause river levels to rise.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this alert if necessary.

Consider activating any property flood protection products if available.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 PM on 04/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise on the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Toller Whelme and Dorchester.
Flooding is possible from 02:00 AM on 05/10/2021.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight causing river levels to rise rapidly.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this alert if necessary.
Consider activating any property flood protection products in Maiden Newton if available.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 PM on 04/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Coly, River Yarty, Umborne Brook

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight from Monday into Tuesday.
Heavy rainfall is forecast across East Devon and is forecast to cause river levels to rise.
Flooding is expected between midnight and 5:30am on Tuesday. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land in the floodplain and roads close to the river in the following areas Seaton, Colyton, Axminster and Axmouth.
Further scattered showers are forecast throughout Tuesday. 
River levels are expected to remain higher than normal throughout this period. Please take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
Our incident response staff are monitoring river levels. We will update this message on Tuesday morning or when the situation changes.

River levels will rise rapidly on the River Cale due to forecast heavy rainfall overnight.
River levels will be at their highest between 02:00 AM and 10:00 AM on 05/10/2021.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Cale and its tributaries.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages and we are clearing debris from weed screens in the area.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which are affected by flooding. 
This message will be updated by 10:00 PM on 04/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

This message will be updated by 10:00 PM on 04/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight and into tomorrow, Tuesday 5 October 2021.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tomorrow, Tuesday 5 October 2021.  Flooding is expected to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Tuesday 5 October 2021 or if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible later this evening on Monday 4th October, and in to the early hours, due to heavy and persistent rain crossing the area. Following frequent rainfall over recent days, the catchment has wetted up and rivers are likely to become more responsive. Levels are expected to peak between 10pm and 4am and may stay high for several hours afterwards. 

The heaviest rainfall is expected to have cleared the area by around 10pm, however further heavy showers are possible throughout the early hours of the morning. 

At present, the anticipated river levels suggest that there may be flooding to low-lying land and roads near rivers, however no flooding to properties is currently expected.  

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area ready to respond as required.

This message will be updated Tuesday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and Swinbourne for West Swindon area to above Water Eaton
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are expected to rise on the River Ray and Swinbourne in response to heavy rainfall forecast overnight tonight, 4 October 2021. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected overnight tonight from midnight, especially in the areas closest to the watercourses in west Swindon. Heavy rainfall is forecast overnight between 9pm and 3am. We expect river levels to rise in response to this rainfall during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 5 October 2021, before dropping during the day tomorrow.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing weed and trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 5 October 2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Great Somerford river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 03:00 and 17:00 tomorrow, 05/10/21.  We believe there is a possibility of flooding for the road at Reybridge.   We do not forecast the situation to deteriorate any further.
We expect river levels to rise until 09:00 on 05/10/21.We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on Tuesday, 05/10/21, or as the situation changes.
